author: suburbandad_
content: regarding backwards sync: is there a threshold that other ELs are using regarding backwards sync vs full sync (with a required hash of a recent finalized block)?

author: suburbandad_
content: like, if we are >X blocks behind, do full (forward) sync.  But if head is <X block behind use backward sync?

author: suburbandad_
content:
when testing besu on kintsugi and devnet4, if we stop the clients for some period of time and then restart, the CL will do an optimistic sync and get "way ahead" of EL.  Then for each block/slot behind we are, we ask the network for the resulting gap, one block at a time backwards.  

Our thinking is that at some threshold of blocks behind, it would be more efficient to instead do a forward sync from peers which have the latest finalized block, stopping at the latest finalized hash/block height.  

I am thinking worst case, we could be led astray by a malicious peer up to the block height of the latest finalized block.  And best case we would reduce the p2p request traffic and time to sync significantly.  Thoughts?

author: suburbandad_
content: Ah scratch that - I wasn't aware of the `reverse` flag on GetBlockHeaders.  https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/caps/eth.md#getblockheaders-0x03
